ISR@PRIM.text:
%-----------------------  ISPF/PDF PRIMARY OPTION MENU  ------------------------
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
%   0 +ISPF PARMS  - Specify terminal and user parameters   +TIME     - &ZTIME
%   1 +BROWSE      - Display source data or output listings +TERMINAL - &ZTERM
%   2 +EDIT        - Create or change source data           +PF KEYS  - &ZKEYS
%   3 +UTILITIES   - Perform utility functions              +LOGON    - &ZLOGON
%   4 +FOREGROUND  - Invoke language processors in foreground +DATE   - &ZDATE
%   5 +BATCH       - Submit job for language processing      +JDATE   - &ZJDATE
%   6 +COMMAND     - Enter TSO command or CLIST             +PREFIX   - &ZPREFIX
%   7 +DIALOG TEST - Perform dialog testing                 +APPLID   - &ZAPPLID
%   8 +LM UTILITIES- Perform library management utility functions
%   C +CHANGES     - Display summary of changes for this release
%   D +NASPA dialog- Data Set Name Table
%   I +INFO/MVS    - Information Systems
%   P +PANVALET    - Browse, edit, and utilities
%  PX +PANEXEC     - Utilities
%   Q +Info Center - TSO/E Info Center
%   R +SAR         - SYSOUT Archival and Retrieval
%   U +UCB DISPLAY - UCB dialog Manager
%   V +VTOC        - VTOC Dialog Manager
%   T +TUTORIAL    - ISPF/PDF tutorial
% PDS +PDS         - Invoke the PDS command processor
%   X +EXIT        - Exit ISPF using log/list defaults
+Enter%END+command to terminate ISPF.
)INIT
  .HELP = ISR00003
  &ZPRIM = YES        /* ALWAYS A PRIMARY OPTION MENU      */
  &ZHTOP = ISR00003   /* TUTORIAL TABLE OF CONTENTS        */
  &ZHINDEX = ISR91000 /* TUTORIAL INDEX - 1ST PAGE         */
  VPUT (ZHTOP,ZHINDEX) PROFILE
)PROC
  &ZSEL = TRANS( TRUNC (&ZCMD,'.')
                0,'PANEL(ISPOPTA)'
                1,'PGM(ISRBRO) PARM(ISRBRO01)'
                2,'PGM(ISREDIT) PARM(P,ISREDM01)'
                3,'PANEL(ISRUTIL)'
                4,'PANEL(ISRFPA)'
                5,'PGM(ISRJB1) PARM(ISRJPA) NOCHECK'
                6,'PGM(ISRPTC)'
                7,'PGM(ISRYXDR) NOCHECK'
                8,'PANEL(ISRLPRIM)'
                C,'PGM(ISPTUTOR) PARM(ISR00005)'
                D,'PGM(MDM0000) NEWAPPL(MDM)'
                I,'PGM(BLGINIT) NEWAPPL(BLG0) PARM(SESS(00))'
                P,'PGM(PSPILINI) NOCHECK'
               PX,'PGM(PXP0000) NEWAPPL(PXP)'
                Q,'PANEL(ICQGCM00) NEWAPPL(ICQ)'
                R,'PGM(SARSPF) PARM(HRA.SAR) NEWAPPL(SAR)'
                U,'PGM(UCB0000)'
                V,'PGM(VDM0000) NEWAPPL(VDM)'
                T,'PGM(ISPTUTOR) PARM(ISR00000)'
              PDS,'PANEL(PDS@PRIM)'
              ' ',' '
                X,'EXIT'
                *,'?' )
  &ZTRAIL = .TRAIL
)END

PXPIMACB.text:
ISREDIT MACRO
ISPEXEC CONTROL ERRORS RETURN
ISREDIT DELETE .ZFIRST
ISREDIT DELETE .ZLAST
/* ISREDIT CHANGE P'=' '' ALL 1 1 ,SEE P35 COL DEPENDENT DATA */
/* ISREDIT RESET  CHANGE  */
ISREDIT (VAR) = LINENUM .ZLAST    /* GET LAST LINE NUM */
DO WHILE &VAR GT 0                /* SHIFT ALL LINES 1 CHAR TO LEFT */
   ISREDIT SHIFT ( &VAR 1         /* TO ELIMINATE CARRIAGE CONTROL  */
   SET VAR = &VAR - 1
END
ISREDIT END
EXIT CODE(0)

PXPIMACE.text:

ISPEXEC CONTROL ERRORS RETURN

DO WHILE &VAR GT 0                /* SHIFT ALL LINES 1 CHAR TO LEFT */

END

PXPVOLD.text:
/* DOC: PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - GET VOLSER FOR DELETE TAPE
CONTROL MSG NOLIST
ISPEXEC VGET (SPXPDSN) SHARED
NEXTGEN  DSN('HRA.PANXDEL.&SPXPDSN')          /*  GET G0000V00 */
IF &LASTCC ¬= 0 THEN -
  DO
   SET VOLSER = &STR(      )
   GOTO NOVOLSER
  END
FILEINFO DSN('HRA.PANXDEL.&SPXPDSN..&CURGEN')  /*  GET VOLSER  */
NOVOLSER: -
ISPEXEC VPUT (VOLSER) SHARED

PXPVOLR.text:
/* DOC: PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - GET VOLSER FOR RESTORE TAPE
CONTROL MSG NOLIST
ISPEXEC VGET (SPXPDSN LIBGDG LIBGDGAB) SHARED
IF &STR(&LIBGDG) = &STR() THEN -
  DO
   SET GDGNO = &LIBGDGAB
   GOTO GETVOL
  END
NEXTGEN  DSN('HRA.PANXBKUP.&SPXPDSN')        /* GET G0000V00 */
SET GDGNO  = &SUBSTR(2:5,&CURGEN)
SET GDGNO  = &GDGNO + &LIBGDG       /* ADJUST     */
GETVOL:-
SET PADLEN = 4 - &LENGTH(&GDGNO)
IF  &PADLEN = 0 THEN -
   FILEINFO DSN('HRA.PANXBKUP.&SPXPDSN..G&STR(&GDGNO)V00')  /*VOLSER */
ELSE -
   FILEINFO -
   DSN('HRA.PANXBKUP.&SPXPDSN..G&STR(&SUBSTR(1:&PADLEN,000)&GDGNO)V00')
IF &LASTCC ¬= 40 THEN SET VOLSER = &STR(      )  /* FILE ON TAPE VOL */
ISPEXEC VPUT (VOLSER) SHARED

PXP000@.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC - TERMINATION ------------------------ TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  You can terminate PANEXEC when the PANEXEC primary option panel is
   displayed by:
     - issuing the%END+command or
     - issuing the%RETURN+command

+  When you issue the END or the RETURN command on the PANEXEC primary
   option menu, when not in split screen mode, PANEXEC terminates
   immediately. In split screen mode, only the logical screen is
   terminated.

   The ISPF panel from which PANEXEC was invoked is then displayed.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000B1.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- GENERAL INFORMATION --------------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
        The PANEXEC/ISPF dialog uses panels to allow you to select
   options and to specify parameters and commands to simplify requests
   for PANEXEC functions, and provide ISPF services for information display,
   browsing, editing, etc. (including complete TUTORIAL and HELP
   facilities).  It is assumed that the user is already familiar with the
   operation of the batch PANEXEC system as described in the PANEXEC SYSTEM
   REFERENCE MANUAL.  A knowledge of the following is also essential to
   completely understand this dialog:
     ISPF/PDF
     JCL
     LINKAGE EDITOR
     COMPILERS/ASSEMBLER
     TSO/E COMMAND PROCEDURES (CLISTS)
     PANVALET BATCH AND SUBSYSTEM (optional)
     TOP SECRET SECURITY (optional)

        The PANEXEC/ISPF dialog was wholly developed by MORRIS KARLIN
   of HRA/MIS, BUREAU OF TECHNICAL SERVICES and is not a product of
   COMPUTER ASSOCIATES.
                        (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
   &Zcont = pxp000b2
)END

PXP000B2.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- GENERAL INFORMATION --------------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
      PANEXEC provides programmer facilities for maintaining object
and executable programs in a fashion similar to the way PANVALET
provides for source programs.
      In particular PANEXEC provides:

  - Control over executable programs
  - Library information (on load libraries) for audit and management
  - Library reorganization without halting processing
  - Ability to selectively restore from backup tapes
  - Programmer functions
    . add, change, copy, execute, compile, link, retrieve, print, etc.
  - Efficient utilization of DASD
    . utilities to identify and delete unused/temporary programs
    . minimize disk contention
    . DASD error protection
  - Security (native PANEXEC and external security through security
    interface exits) on programs and commands

                        (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
   &Zcont = pxp000b3
)END

PXP000B3.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- GENERAL INFORMATION --------------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
  - Management type functions
    . create a PANEXEC library
    . create a backup of entire/partial library
    . remove, restore, transfer programs from a PANEXEC library
    . establish, change security access codes
  - EASYTRIEVE report writer language to provide management information
    (correlate load and source programs, identify unused programs for
    archival, etc.)

  The follwoing topics will be preseneted only if selected by number:

   %1+- Software requirements for running PANEXEC/ISPF
   %2+- DASD and space requirements for installing and running PANEXEC/ISPF
   %3+- Installing PANEXEC/ISPF

)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000b5
                2,*pxp000b4
                3,*pxp000b6
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000B4.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- GENERAL INFORMATION --------------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+   DASD AND SPACE REQUIREMENTS FOR INSTALLING AND RUNNING PANEXEC/ISPF

    DASD requirements:
        PANEXEC/ISPF requires DASD that can support physical BLKSIZEs of
    23476 (IBM 3380 or 3390 or compatible) for intermediate work files.

       Minimum SPACE requirements for PANEXEC/ISPF libraries (assuming 3380
    type devices) are:
                                   TRACKS  DIRECTORY BLOCKS  NUMBER OF MEMBERS
    1. Load library     (ISPLLIB)    10           10                7
    2. Panel library    (ISPPLIB)    10           20              102
    3. Message library  (ISPMLIB)     1            2                4
    4. Skeleton library (ISPSLIB)     2            2                3
    5. Table library    (ISPTLIB)     1            1                1
    6. CLIST library    (SYSPROC)     1            2                4
    7. Source library   (optional)   13            5                9
    8. Macro library    (optional)   25           20               86
    9. PANEXEC Command Procedures     2            5                9

    TSO/E REGION requirements:
       Users should LOGON to TSO/E with a minimum REGION size of 2000K.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000b3
)END

PXP000B5.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- GENERAL INFORMATION --------------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
        SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS FOR RUNNING PANEXEC/ISPF

        The following minimal software configuration is required for running
    PANEXEC/ISPF:

    1. MVS/SP V1.3.5
    2. TSO/E V1.3
    3. ISPF/PDF V2.3
    4. PANEXEC  V5.2
    5. PANVALET V14.1  (optional)
    6. TOP SECRET R4.2 (optional security software)

)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000b3
)END

PXP000B6.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- INSTALLING PANEXEC/ISPF ----------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
    To install the PANEXEC/ISPF dialog, members from the distribution
 libraries must be placed into the appropiate ISPF library concatenation (in
 either the TSO LOGON PROC or the ISPF invocation CLIST).  PANEXEC/ISPF is
 distributed in five (5) PDSs. The first PDS contains all the source members
 necessary for the ISPxLIB (x=P, M, S, T) and SYSPROC files. The second PDS
 contains all the load modules necessary for the ISPLLIB file. The table
 below details the appropiate members to be moved into each library.

      ISPF LIBRARY
      CONCATENATION              M E M B E R S

    1. ISPPLIB         PXP000x(x), PXP001x(x), PXP002x, PXP0x03, PXPLOGO,
                       PXPBROBF,   PXPEDDE
    2. ISPMLIB         PXP0x
    3. ISPSLIB         PXP000xS, PXP0010S
    4. ISPLLIB         all members of file 2 (PXP000x,  PXP0010, PXP0100)
    5. SYSPROC(CLISTs) PXPVOLx, PXPIMACx
    6. ISPTLIB/ISPTABL PXPCMDS

               (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000b3
   &Zcont = pxp000b7
)END

PXP000B7.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- INSTALLING PANEXEC/ISPF ----------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
    To enable PANEXEC/ISPF to be invoked from an ISPF menu, option PX should
 be placed into an ISPF selection panel with the following line added to the
 processing section:

         PX,'PGM(PXP0000) NEWAPPL(PXP)'
 (for an example, see member ISP@PRIM in file 1).

    The macro library (file 3 on the distribution tape, courtesy of the
 National Systems Programmers Association (NaSPA) with some modifications
 and additions by the author) and source library (file 4) are not required
 for installing PANEXEC/ISPF but are supplied for users who may wish to
 customize PANEXEC/ISPF to their own installations requirements.  Member
 ASMHCL in the source library may be used assemble and link-edit the source
 modules. If a TOP SECRET security interface is desired, module $PANXSEC is
 supplied in source form and must be assembled and link-edited into
 STEPLIB/LINKLIB (and specified in the PANEXEC PANEOPT macro as a
 security exit invoking events $EXEC000, $ELEM000, $ELEM001 and $CMND000).

                  (contiued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000b3
   &Zcont = pxp000b8
)END

PXP000B8.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC- INSTALLING PANEXEC/ISPF ----------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
    The fifth file contains PANEXEC Command Procedures which are required
 for the following portions of the PANEXEC/ISPF dialog:

     PANEXEC/ISPF Compile/Link-Edit dialog
     PANEXEC/ISPF Library Maintenance dialog

    Six Command Procedures are required for the Compile/Link-Edit dialog-
 PXASM, PXCVS, PXPL1, PXFORT, PXOPT and PXLK.
    Three Command Procedures are required for the Library Maintenance dialog-
 PXSTBKUP, PXCREATP and PXRESTRP.

    Member STORE is supplied in this file to allow users to add the above
 Command Procedures to the PANESRL library. The dialog assumes that these
 Command Procedure are type 'CNTL' and are in 'TA' status.  These Command
 Procedures may be customized prior to installation and additional
 procedures may be written depending on need (e.g., if the installation
 wishes to support additional compilers).
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000b3
)END

PXP000CA.text:
%TUTORIAL ---- PANEXEC - ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - 'SAVE' COMMAND ------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%SAVE+command writes the element list to the ISPF LIST data set.

+  The command syntax is:   %COMMAND ===> save {n}

   An integer value of 1, 2 or 3 may be specified for n in the SAVE command.
   If n is not specified or is specified as 2 (or is not a valid value) then
   a 2-line directory listing for each directory element is sent to the ISPF
   LIST data set. If n is specified as 1, then a truncated 1-line listing is
   sent to the LIST data set. If n is specified as 3 then a full 3-line
   directory listing is sent to the ISPF LIST data set.

   The element list is sent in its current sort order. Unprocessed line
   commands are omitted.  The element list is formatted the way it
   appears on the screen (the PANVALET DATA SET NAME and DESCRIPTION
   fields are truncated) with abbreviated heading line(s).

   The ISPF LIST data set should be defined with a minimum LRECL of 128 in
   ISPF option 0.5 (LIST data set characteristics) to avoid truncation of
   significant data.

   The current ISPF LIST data set is &zlstname.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CB.text:
%TUTORIAL ---- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - 'RESET' COMMAND ------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   The%RESET+command resets the line command field on the element list.
   Unprocessed line commands are erased.
)PROC
  &ZUP = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CC.text:
%TUTORIAL --- PANEXEC - ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - LOCATE COMMAND -------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The following example shows how to locate an element by name.

+                               |%COMMAND ===> l test.aaa11
+  The example at the right     |        Fully Qualified Name  Coresize Linkedit
+  shows how to scroll directly |    Group    Element  Type SM Required   Date
+  to the elements beginning    |    PROD    .ABC100  /EXEC;TA  0010408 11/20/89
+  with AAA11 in group TEST.    |    PROD    .ABC150  /EXEC;TD  0000100 11/25/89
+                               |    PROD    .QRS005  /EXEC;PA  0015000 10/15/88
+                               |    TEST    .AAA100  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83
+                               |    TEST    .AAA110  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83
+                               |    TEST    .AAA115  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83

+                               |%COMMAND ===> l test.zzz100/exec,ti
+ The example at the right      |        Fully Qualified Name  Coresize Linkedit
+ shows how to scroll directly  |    Group    Element  Type SM Required   Date
+ to element TEST.ZZZ100/EXEC,TI|    TEST    .ABC100  /EXEC;TA  0010408 11/20/89
+ NOTE that a comma (,) instead |    TEST    .ABC150  /EXEC;TD  0000100 11/25/89
+ of a semi-colon (;) must be   |    TEST    .QRS005  /EXEC;PA  0015000 10/15/88
+ used in the L command.        |    TEST    .ZZZ100  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83
+                               |    TEST    .ZZZ100  /EXEC;TI  0000455 09/10/83
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CD.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - 'SORT' COMMAND ------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The following are valid%SORT+fields for PANEXEC library element lists.
   (Refer to the element selection lists - 'STATISTICS' for a complete
   description of the fields.)  Sort sequence indicates either A (ascending) or
   D (descending). The field abbreviation must be used on the SORT command. A
   blank field abbreviation defaults to NAME.  The panel number indicates the
   relative panel number on which the field appears (scrolling to the right).
                                      Panel
        Field            Abbrev Sequ  number
--------------------------------------------
 %FULLY QUALIFIED NAME    NAME    A    All
 %CORESIZE REQUIRED       CORE    D     1
 %LINKEDIT DATE           LINK    D     1
 %ALIAS-OF                ALIA    A     1
 %LINKEDIT ATTRIBUTES     ----    -     1
 %AC (AUTHORIZATION CODE) AC      D     1
 %PROD DATE               PROD    D     1
 %ACCESS DATE             ACCD    D     2
 %ACCESS TIME (secondary to ACCD) D     2
 %MAINT DATE              MAIN    D     2
 %MAINT TIME  (secondary to MAIN) D     2
                          (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
   &Zcont= pxp000cl
)END

PXP000CE.text:
%TUTORIAL ---- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - STATISTICS -----------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
 AC .................. the authorization code assigned to this element via the
                       linkage-editor SETCODE subcommand or the 'AC=' JCL parm
 PROD DATE ........... date this element became production
 ACCESS DATE ......... date of the most recent access to this element
 ACCESS TIME ......... time of day of the most recent access to this element
 MAINT DATE .......... date of the most recent modification to this element
 MAINT TIME .......... time of day when the most recent modification was
                       made to this element
 EXEC DATE ........... date this program was last executed
 ACTION .............. last command used on this element
 ACCESS MODIF ........ number of times this element has been accessed since
                       it was modified
 ACCESS TOTAL ........ total number of times this element has been accessed
                       it was added
 EXECS MODIF ......... total executions since the element was last modified
 JOBNAME ............. name of job in which this element was last accessed
 STEPNAME ............ step in which this element was last referenced
 ADD DATE ............ date this element was added to the PANEXEC file
                       via the %ADD command
+                  (continued on the next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
   &Zcont = pxp000cf
)END

PXP000CF.text:
%TUTORIAL ---- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - STATISTICS -----------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
 ZAPS ................ Y indicates the element has been zapped
 PANV NAME ........... the PANVALET source name used to create the module
 PANV CL ............. the status (prod/test) and mode (active/inactive/disable)
                       of the source program
 PANV LVL ............ the maintenance level of the source program
 PANV MNT DATE ....... the maintenance date of the source program
 PANV TYPE ........... the type (COBOL, BAL, FORTRAN,etc.) of the source program
 PANV LIBRARY DSN .... the data set name of the PANVALET library
 OWNER ............... owner responsible for this element - documentation only
 DESCRIPTION ......... general description of the element - documentation only
 BACKUP DATE ......... date this element was most recently backed up via BACKUP
 RESTORE DATE ........ date this element was most recently restored to PANEXEC
 REMOVE DATE ......... date this element was removed from the PANEXEC file
 USER ................ any 4 characters - documentation only
 ACCOUNT ............. identify which account element belongs to- documentation
 SYSTEM .............. the system which this element is part of - documentation
+
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CG.text:
%TUTORIAL ---- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - PERFORMANCE ISSUES ---TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   When utilizing the S (display element selection list) option there are
   several performance issues which must be taken into account.  By the
   very nature of the PANEXEC library structure, access to the entire
   PANEXEC directory may require a considerable amount of system resources
   (especially I/O) which may cause unacceptable delays in displaying
   element selection lists. This is especially true for PANEXEC libraries
   containing many elements (over several hundred) and will depend on the
   scope of the element selection list requested and the particular
   PANEXEC primary commands issued from the element selection list.

   For this reason, the DISPLAY VIEW field has been incorporated into the
   primary PANEXEC utility panel. When the Short (S) option is chosen (the
   default), the element selection list will be displayed relatively
   quickly, even for large PANEXEC libraries. However, NO source PANVALET
   information will be displayed for executable elements even when there is
   PANVALET information contained in the directory for those elements. In
   order to display all PANVALET source information in the element
   selection list panel the Long (L) option of DISPLAY VIEW field must be
   chosen, but users are cautioned that this option adds a very significant
   amount of overhead in displaying the element selection list.
                      (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
   &cont  = pxp000ch
)END

PXP000CH.text:
%TUTORIAL ---- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - PERFORMANCE ISSUES ---TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
   For example, over seven (7) minutes in wall-time were required to display
   the element selection list for a PANEXEC librarary containing 6400
   elements on an IBM 4381 processor using the Long option as compared to
   only two minutes required for the same display using the Short option.

   The following options and commands will also impact performance
   in creating or accessing an element selection display independent of
   the setting of the the DISPLAY VIEW field:
   1. Requesting an element selection list by generic element name -
      since the PANEXEC directory is processed in alphabetical order,
      choosing a generic name criteria which requests elements from the
      end of the directory will cause more of a delay than choosing
      elements from the beginning of the directory.
   2. For large PANEXEC libraries, delays will be perceived the first
      time one of the following commands are issued:
        L (locate), SAVE, SORT, scroll DOWN MAX
      Any subsequent use of the same or other command in the above list
      should NOT cause additional processing delays.
   3. Delays will be perceived for any large scroll down (several
      hundred lines) until the bottom of the directory is displayed or
      until any of the commands in (2) above are issued, after which no
      additional processing delays should occur.
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CI.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------PANEXEC -ELEMENT SELECTION LIST - DUPLICATE ELEMENTS-TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   Duplicate elements in the PANEXEC library (i.e., multiple disabled or
   inactive versions of the same element) are all displayed in the
   element selection list. However, when processing duplicate elements
   via line commands, only the last accessed duplicate element is
   accessible; all the other duplicate elements within that group are
   inaccessible.  This is true for all line commands except the 'D'
   (delete element) command. The 'D' command specified for any one
   duplicate element will delete ALL duplicate elements within the
   duplicate group from the PANEXEC library (although only one entry
   from the element selection list will be deleted.  The other duplicate
   directory entries will remain as inaccessible 'orphan' entries and
   will disappear the next time the element selection list is
   redisplayed).

   Duplicate elements are created in an element selection list via the
   'M' (modify mode) and the 'PM' (promote) line commands only.
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CJ.text:
%TUTORIAL ------- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - SCROLLING -------- TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The command syntax for scrolling to the RIGHT or LEFT is:
           %COMMAND ===> right {n}  or    %COMMAND ===> left {n}

   Scrolling to the right/left displays additional statistical fields
   for each element. The right/left direction in which you may scroll is
   indicated by the (MORE<=m=>) field in the upper right corner of the
   panel with the 1 or 2-directional arrow indicating the permissible
   scroll direction(s) and the imbedded m indicating the logical
   horizontal panel number. Currently, there are 6 horizontal panels.

   An integer value may be specified for n in the scroll command.
   Coding n in the scroll command allows n panels to be scrolled
   horizontally with one command.  If n is not specified or is specified
   as 1 then the screen scrolled one panel to the right/left.  The word
   MAX (or its abbreviation, M) may also be coded for n in which case
   the rightmost/leftmost panel is scrolled to.  If a scroll amount is
   specified that would cause scrolling beyond the rightmost/leftmost
   panel then scrolling is performed as if M had been specified.

)PROC
  &ZUP = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CK.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - PANEL INTERACTIONS --TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  Most line commands entered from an element selection list will cause
   another panel to be displayed to allow completion of the line command
   issued, with cursor positioned at the field(s) requiring completion.
   E.g., if the R (rename) line command is issued against an element,
   the primary PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY panel will be displayed with the
   cursor positioned at the NEW ELEMENT field to allow entry of a new
   element and/or group name.

   In addition, if an error is made on an element selection list another
   panel may be displayed with the cursor positioned on the field in
   error accompanied by an error message in the upper right corner of
   the panel. E.g., if the D (delete) line command is issued against an
   active element (MODE=A) then the primary PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY
   PANEL is displayed with the cursor positioned at the MODE field and
   the error message INVALID MODE VALUE in the upper right corner of the
   panel. The HELP command may be entered for a longer explanatory
   message (if one exists). The END command must be entered to continue
   processing any remaining line commands and then return to the element
   selection list.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000CL.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - 'SORT' COMMAND ------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+                                 Panel
    Field            Abbrev Sequ  number
-----------------------------------------
 %EXEC DATE           EXEC    D     2
 %ACTION              ACTN    A     2
 %ACCESS MODIF        ACCM    D     3
 %ACCESS TOTAL        ACCT    D     3
 %EXECS MODIF         EXEM    D     3
 %JOBNAME             JOB     A     3
 %STEPNAME (secondary to JOB) A     3
 %ADD DATE            ADD     D     3
 %ZAPS                ZAPS    D     3
 %PANV NAME           PVNM    A     4
 %PANV CL (CLASS)     ----    -     4
 %PANV LVL (LEVEL)    ----    -     4
 %PANV MNT DATE       ----    -     4
 %PANV TYPE           ----    -     4
 %PANV LIB DSN (primary for PVNM)   4
 %OWNER               OWN     A     5
 %DESCRIPTION         ----    -     5

                          (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
   &Zcont = pxp000cm
)END

PXP000CM.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - 'SORT' COMMAND ------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+                                 Panel
    Field            Abbrev Sequ  number
-----------------------------------------
 %BACKUP DATE         ----    -     6
 %RESTORE DATE        REST    D     6
 %REMOVE DATE         REMV    D     6
 %USER                USER    A     6
 %ACCOUNT             ACC     A     6
 %SYSTEM              SYST    A     6

)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000C0.text:
%TUTORIAL ------------PANEXEC -ELEMENT SELECTION LIST ------------------TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   The S option displays an element selection list of all or a portion of
   the elements in a PANEXEC library.  You may scroll through the list via
   the%UP+%DOWN+%RIGHT+and%LEFT+scroll commands or via the%LOCATE+command,
   and you may browse one element at a time via the%S+primary command or
   select elements for processing via line commands (browse, edit, print,
   copy, etc.). The element selection list itself may be sorted via the
   SORT command or may be written to the ISPF LIST data set via the SAVE
   command or may be cleared of all line commands via the RESET command.

   To display an element selection list:
       - Enter%S+in the option field on the library utility panel.
       - Enter the%library+information in the appropriate fields. The
         DATASET NAME field is required; TYPE, STATUS and MODE are optional.
       - Specify blank or generic element name or complete element name.
   The message 'BUILDING DIRECTORY' will display below the command line
   while the dialog constructs the element selection list.

   To automatically clear the GROUP, ELEMENT, TYPE, STATUS and MODE fields
   enter the "X" option. The "S" option then automatically replaces "X".
   NOTE: See PERFORMANCE Issues on choosing an appropriate DISPLAY VIEW.
                           (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000a
   &ZCONT = pxp000c1
)END

PXP000C1.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC - ELEMENT SELECTION LIST-------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   To reach a specific element name in a list, use the scroll commands
   (%UP+or%DOWN+) or the%LOCATE+command.  You can select one or more
   elements for processing by entering any valid line command in front
   of the desired elements or you may browse the element by using the S
   (select) primary command.

   After you have finished using the element selection list, enter
   the%END+ command to return to the PANEXEC utility panel.  To display
   an updated element list, request an element selection list again.

  %Caution:+ Do not enter the END command until all your requests have been
   processed.  If unprocessed requests remain when you enter END, they will
   not be processed.
                           (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000a
   &ZCONT = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000C2.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------PANEXEC -ELEMENT SELECTION LIST ---------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
%

+The following topics will be presented only if selected by number:

    %1+-  Element Selection List - Scrolling
    %2+-  Element Selection List - Generic name matching
    %3+-  Element Selection List - L (locate) command
    %4+-  Element Selection List - SORT command
    %5+-  Element Selection List - S (select) command
    %6+-  Element Selection List - SAVE command
    %7+-  Element Selection List - RESET command
    %8+-  Element Selection List - Line commands
    %9+-  Element Selection List - Statistics
    %10+- Element Selection List - Performance Issues
    %11+- Element Selection List - Duplicate elements
    %12+- Element Selection List - Panel Interactions
    %13+- Element Selection List - DIAGNOSE command
    %14+- Element Selection List - CONFIRM delete command
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000c3
                2,*pxp000c4
                3,*pxp000c5
                4,*pxp000c6
                5,*pxp000c7
                6,*pxp000ca
                7,*pxp000cb
                8,*pxp000c8
                9,*pxp000c9
               10,*pxp000cg
               11,*pxp000ci
               12,*pxp000ck
               13,*pxp000x
               14,*pxp002a
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000C3.text:
%TUTORIAL ------- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - SCROLLING -------- TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  Scrolling in element selection lists is done the same way as for
   browse and edit.

    - To scroll down/up by the scroll amount, enter a%DOWN/UP+command.
    - To scroll to the right/left, enter a%RIGHT/LEFT+command.

   You may change the scroll amount field at the top of the display as
   in browse or edit.  Another method of scrolling is to use the L
   (locate) command, which is described in the tutorial,%"ELEMENT
   SELECTION LISTS - LOCATE COMMAND".+

   Scrolling (UP or DOWN) may be performed when issuing line commands.
   The scroll request is processed only after all line commands have
   been processed. (Any secondary help messages, however, will be lost
   after the scroll).  Line commands are reset when scrolling RIGHT or
   LEFT.

                  (continued on next page)
)PROC
  &ZUP = pxp000c2
  &Zcont = pxp000cj
)END

PXP000C4.text:
%TUTORIAL -- PANEXEC-ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - GENERIC NAME MATCHING -- TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   A generic element name allows you to specify a subset of the elements
   in a PANEXEC library.

   The generic name is specified as:

          %string*+

   where%"string"+is a character string of length n, where 0 < n < 8.
   For an element to match a generic name, the first n characters of the
   element name must match the n characters of%"string".+ The
   asterisk%(*),+if used, implies a match of the remaining characters in
   the element name. If an element matches the generic name, it is
   included.  Omitting the asterisk causes%string+to be used as an exact
   element name match.

)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000C5.text:
%TUTORIAL -- PANEXEC - ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - LOCATE COMMAND --------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The locate command (which must be entered as %L+) scrolls to the
   entry you specify or the one preceding it on the display if the entry
   is not found. Syntax is as follows:

        %L string+

   where%"string"+can be up to 25 characters long.  It is compared with the
   values of the fully qualified element names and must correspond
   syntactically to PANEXEC naming conventions, i.e., the proper delimiter
   must separate the group name ('.'), element name ('/'), type name (',' -
   a semi-colon (';'), the default command stacking delimiter, may%NOT+be
   used) and status and mode.  You must specify all delimiters up to the
   last qualifier you require (even if intermediate qualifiers are not
   specified). If the last qualifier(s) are missing, then you may omit their
   associated delimiters.  If%"string"+is found, that entry is scrolled to
   the top of the display.  If it is not found, the entry preceding it is
   scrolled to the top of the display.

   The L command may be used with element name only and no other field
   of the element selection list.
                             (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
   &ZCONT = pxp000cc
)END

PXP000C6.text:
%TUTORIAL --- PANEXEC - ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - 'SORT' COMMAND ------ TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%SORT+command sorts an element list by the fields displayed on the
   element list. The field names that may be used in the SORT command
   and their sort sequence are listed on the next page of this tutorial.

+                               |%COMMAND ===> sort link
+  The example at the right     |        Fully Qualified Name  Coresize Linkedit
+  shows how to sort the element|    Group    Element  Type SM Required   Date
+  list by Linkedit Date.       |    TEST    .ABC100  /EXEC;TA  0010408 11/20/89
+                               |    TEST    .ABC150  /EXEC;TD  0000100 11/25/89
+                               |    TEST    .QRS005  /EXEC;PA  0015000 10/15/88
+                               |    TEST    .ZZZ100  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83

                            (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
   &ZCONT = pxp000cd
)END

PXP000C7.text:
%TUTORIAL -PANEXEC ELEMENT SELECTION LIST- S (SELECT) PRIMARY COMMAND --TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   Use the%select+command (which must be entered as%S+) to browse an
   element from the element list.

   You can browse one element at a time, by entering a%S+command (shown
   below) or by entering the single character%"B"+in front of the
   element name (view the tutorials entitled%"element SELECTION LISTS -
   SINGLE element SELECTION".) Not every qualifier of the element name
   need be specified if the qualifier default value will cause selection
   of the correct element. The rules for specifying the element name are
   the same as for the L (locate) command.

+                               |%COMMAND ===> s test.zzz100/exec,ta
+ The example at the right      |        Fully Qualified Name  Coresize Linkedit
+ shows how to browse element   |    Group    Element  Type SM Required   Date
+ TEST.ZZZ100/EXEC,TA           |    TEST    .ABC100  /EXEC;TA  0010408 11/20/89
+ NOTE that a comma (,) instead |    TEST    .ABC150  /EXEC;TD  0000100 11/25/89
+ of a semi-colon (;) must be   |    TEST    .QRS005  /EXEC;PA  0015000 10/15/88
+ used in the S command.        |    TEST    .ZZZ100  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83
+                               |    TEST    .ZZZ100  /EXEC;TI  0000455 09/10/83
+  The S command could have been specified as S TEST.ZZZ100 if the
+  default type, status and mode were EXEC, T and A.
)PROC
   &ZUP   = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000C8.text:
%TUTORIAL --- PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - LINE COMMANDS ---------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   You can select one or more elements for processing from the element selection
   list by entering any valid line command in front of each element name. You
   can use the cursor control keys to position the cursor on the desired lines.
   Any of the functions described on the primary PANEXEC library utility panel
   may be used as line commands on an element selection list. Any line commands
   entered, however, will be ignored if a primary command is entered.

   When an element is renamed (R), promoted (PM), copied (C), deleted (D), or
   has its mode modified (M) the element selection list is updated by adding
   and/or deleting the element name. The other statistics, however, are not
   updated until the element selection list is re-displayed.

+                               |%COMMAND ===>
+  The example at the right     |        Fully Qualified Name  Coresize Linkedit
+  shows how element PROD.ABC100|    Group    Element  Type SM Required   Date
+  is printed, PROD.ABC150 is   |%p +PROD    .ABC100  /EXEC;TA  0010408 11/20/89
+  deleted, PROD.QRS005 is      |%d +PROD    .ABC150  /EXEC;TD  0000100 11/25/89
+  browsed, TEST.AAA100 is      |%b +PROD    .QRS005  /EXEC;PA  0015000 10/15/88
+  renamed, TEST.AAA110 is      |%r +TEST    .AAA100  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83
+  copied and TEST.AAA115 has   |%c +TEST    .AAA110  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83
+  its mode modified.           |%m +TEST    .AAA115  /EXEC;TA  0000455 09/10/83
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
)END

PXP000C9.text:
%TUTORIAL ------ PANEXEC- ELEMENT SELECTION LISTS - STATISTICS ---------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
   PANEXEC automatically generates and maintains the following statistics
   for each element of a PANEXEC library.

 CORESIZE REQUIRED ... core required to load this element into main storage
 LINKEDIT DATE ....... link edit date - set by the panlink processor only
 ALIAS-OF ............ the main module for which this element is an alias
 LINKEDIT ATTRIBUTES . load module attributes established by the linkage editor
                       the attributes dispalyed are:
                       RN - module has been marked reentrant
                       RU - module has been marked reusable
                       OV - module has been marked as an overlay
                       TS - module has been linked with the test attribute
                       OL - module has been marked load only
                       SC - module is scatter load format
                       NX - module has been marked not executable
                       FO - module can only be processed by the level F linkage
                            editor
                       RF - module has been marked refreshable
                       NE - module is non-editable (cannot be relinked From an
                            executable format)
                       Y indicates that the attribute is 'on'
+                             (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000c2
   &Zcont = pxp000ce
)END

PXP000D.text:
%TUTORIAL ------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - FETCH ELEMENT---------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%fetch element+function is used to fetch an element of a PANEXEC
   library into a partitioned or sequential data set.  (Use the%element
   list+option if you wish to fetch several elements.)

+  To perform a fetch operation, fill in the following fields on the
   library utility panel and press the%ENTER+key:

     - Enter%F+in the option field.
     - Enter the%"from"+library information in the appropriate fields.
     - Enter an element name in the element field.

 NOTE:  If there are embedded INCLUDEs in the element to be fetched, those
 INCLUDEd elements must be found in the PANEXEC library for the fetch
 operation to be successful (whether or not the INCLUDEs are to be expanded
 or not). WARNING: CNTL elements containing linkage editor INCLUDE control
 statements CANNOT be fetched because PANEXEC (mis)interprets the INCLUDE
 DDNAME(PROGNAME) as a PANEXEC INCLUDE statement for element
 DDNAME.PROGNAME/OBJ which is probably not on the library.

 The following topics will be presented only if selected by number:
    %1+- FETCH UTILITY - SECOND PANEL
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp001a1
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000E.text:
%TUTORIAL ------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - ADD ELEMENT----------------   TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%add element+function is used to add an element to a PANEXEC
   library from a partitioned or sequential data set.  (Use the%element
   list+option if you wish to add several elements.)

+  To perform an add operation, fill in the following fields on the
   library utility panel and press the%ENTER+key:

     - Enter%A+in the option field.
     - Enter the%"to"+library information in the appropriate fields.
     - Enter an element name in the element field.

 The following topics will be presented only if selected by number:

    %1+- add utility - second panel
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp001a1
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000F.text:
%TUTORIAL ------ PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - LIBRARY INFORMATION ---------TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  To%display information+about a PANEXEC library, fill in the following
   fields of the library utility panel:
      - Enter%I+in the option field.
      - Enter the%library name in the appropriate fields.
      - Enter any element name of an element that exists on that PANEXEC library

   The information that will be displayed is identical to the report
   'PANEXEC FILE CHARACTERISTICS REPORT FOR TSO PE112T'
   which is shown in the PANEXEC system reference manual on page 7-61.
   The fields listed on that report are described on pages 7-13 thru 7-18.

   NOTE: Make sure that the DISPLAY CC command is in effect when viewing
   library information.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000G1.text:
%TUTORIAL ------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - CHANGE ELEMENT DIRECTORY----- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%change element+function is used to change the directory entry of
   an element.  (Use the%element list+option if you wish to change
   several elements).

   To change a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter%CH+in the option field.
       - Enter the%library+information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the%element+field

   NOTE - A user may change multiple directory fields for an
          element with one execution of the CH option. If any one of
          these changes fails, then the message ELEMENT NOT CHANGED
          will be produced. However, all fields that were correctly
          changed will be modified.
          CHANGE character fields may contain any characters except
          commas. Blanks will be compressed out of the CHANGE field
          unless the field is enclosed in quotes.
                   (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
   &Zcont = pxp000g2
)END

PXP000G2.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY-CHANGE ELEMENT DIRECTORY -------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  PANEXEC automatically generates statistics for each element of a
   PANEXEC library. Other statistics are maintained by PANEXEC but must
   be manually entered by the user. These statistics are basically for
   documentation purposes.  You might want to change these statistics
   for reasons such as the following:

       - A person has left the project, and you wish to reassign some of
         the work.  You might then want to change the%owner+of some
         elements to that of the person assuming responsibility.

       - You have elements that were created or modified from
         non-PANVALET source programs.  You would like to track source
         module information.  The change utility may be used to create
         source module statistics for executable elements.

                    (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
   &Zcont = pxp000g3
)END

PXP000G3.text:
%TUTORIAL --------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - CHANGE ELEMENT DIRECTORY--- TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  PANEXEC directory fields which may be manually changed are listed
   in the PANEXEC system reference manual on page 4-22. Among those of
   interest are:

   Normally PANVALET source information is carried forward automatically
   to the PANEXEC directory when a PANVALET program is compiled and link
   edited using the standard PANEXEC compile/linkedit procedures or
   when done through the PANEXEC/ISPF dialog utility using option CL.
   However, if the source program does not reside on PANVALET or a non-
   standard procedure is used in compiling/linkediting, PANVALET source
   information is not carried forward. In this case the change option
   may modify the following fields to track source information:
     SOURCENAME, SOURCECLSS, SOURCELVL, SOURCEDATE

   Other fields are useful for documentation purposes. They are:
     OWNER, ACCOUNT, DESCRIPTION and SYSTEM

   Finally, a word of caution: be extremely careful in modifying the
   ALIAS field. An element made into an alias via the change command
   incorrectly can cause the module to become un-executable.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000H.text:
%TUTORIAL ------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - PROMOTE ELEMENT-------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%promote element+function is used to promote a element of a
   PANEXEC library to production status.  (Use the%element list+option
   if you wish to promote several elements.)

   To promote a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter%PM+in the option field.
       - Enter the%library information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the%element+field

   NOTE: TOP SECRET authorization is required to promote elements to
         production status.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000I.text:
%TUTORIAL ------------ PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - TRANSFER ELEMENT-------TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%transfer element+function is used to transfer an element(s) of a
   PANEXEC library to a different PANEXEC library.  (Use the%element
   list+option if you wish to transfer several elements). Elements may
   NOT be transfered to the same PANEXEC library.

+  To perform a transfer operation, fill in the following fields on the
   library utility panel and press the%ENTER+key:

     - Enter%T+in the option field.
     - Enter the%"from"+library information in the appropriate fields.
     - Enter an element name in the element field if transfering only one
       element or leave this field blank to transfer a group of elements.

 The following topics will be presented only if selected by number:

    %1+- Transfer option - second panel
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp001a1
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000JA.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - BACKUP --------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
    - PE107 inactivity exception report
      Lists only inactive and disabled elements as well as any element
      not accessed in 6 months.
      NOTE: as part of the processing for this report, every element
      not accessed in over 6 month is automatically inactivated!!!

     A sample listing of each of the above reports is in the PANEXEC
MANUAL - CHAPTER 7 MANAGEMENT REPORTING.

 The following topics are presented only if selected by number:

        1 - BACKUP JCL AND PANEXEC PROCEDURE
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000jb
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000j1
)END

PXP000JC.text:
)attr default(¢+_)
)body
¢TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - BACKUP --------- TUTORIAL
¢OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
             The PXSTBKUP PANEXEC PROCEDURE is as follows:
%LIST,DN OFF
%DIRSTAT,FX PANELIB*,FILEA*
*
%FETCH PANESRL*$EZTLIB.PE101/CNTL;PA,EZTIN*
%EXEC PANESRL*$OS.PANETREV/;P
%FETCH PANESRL*$EZTLIB.PE117/CNTL;PA,EZTIN*
%EXEC PANESRL*$OS.PANETREV/;P
%FETCH PANESRL*$EZTLIB.PE106/CNTL;PA,EZTIN*
%EXEC PANESRL*$OS.PANETREV/;P
%FETCH PANESRL*$EZTLIB.PE108/CNTL;PA,EZTIN*
%EXEC PANESRL*$OS.PANETREV/;P
%FETCH PANESRL*$EZTLIB.PE110/CNTL;PA,EZTIN*
%EXEC PANESRL*$OS.PANETREV/;P
%FETCH PANESRL*$EZTLIB.PE107/CNTL;PA,EZTIN*
%EXEC PANESRL*$OS.PANETREV/;P
%INPUT,S SYSPUNCH*
%BACKUP,F  PANELIB*,PROTECT*
*
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000ja
)END

PXP000J1.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE ------------------ TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   The library maintenance option (L) performs essential library
   maintenance on PANEXEC libraries. This option is available only to
   authorized users (Tech Services and Console Operations).
   The L option generates JCL for the all the maintenace functions
   based on information you enter on the library maintenance
   panel, and then submits the job for batch execution (except for the
   M option, which is executed on-line). A JCL JOB statement at the
   bottom of the panel must be coded.

   The PANEXEC library (and elements) on which maintenance is being
   performed must be specified in the main PANEXEC library utility panel.

 The following topics are presented only if selected by number:

        1 - Backup a PANEXEC library (with directory reports)
        2 - Create a PANEXEC library
        3 - Delete inactive elements of a PANEXEC library
        4 - Modify attributes of a PANEXEC library
        5 - Restore a PANEXEC library
        6 - Convert a PDS into a PANEXEC library
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000j2
                2,*pxp000j3
                3,*pxp000j4
                4,*pxp000j5
                5,*pxp000j6
                6,*pxp000j7
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000J2.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - BACKUP --------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
     This procedure will backup the entire PANEXEC library to a
generation data set on tape.  The GDG index is 'HRA.PANXBKUP.libname'.
The retention period field must specify the number of days the PANEXEC
backup tape is to be retained (default = 7).
     This same job will also produce six (6) reports:

    - PE101 PANEXEC file characteristics
      1 page summary of the PANEXEC library
    - PE117 PANEXEC group summary
      1 page summary of the group names and numbers of types and
      statuses of the elements within groups
    - PE106 PANEXEC element summary
      A comprehensive list of every element on the PANEXEC library
      giving access, change, link and backup date information
    - PE108 PANEXEC executable/source cross reference
      A comprehensive list of every executable element on the PANEXEC
      library, similar to the directory listing of PDS load libraries
      (gives load module sizes and link-edit attributes).

                     (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000j1
   &Zcont = pxp000ja
)END

PXP000J3.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - CREATE --------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
     The library create option should be executed on an as needed basis
to create new PANEXEC libraries or re-create damaged PANEXEC libraries.
A PANEXEC group name must be specified on the main PANEXEC library
utility panel to establish a default group name for the PANEXEC library.

 The following fields must be specified on the library maintenance panel
   Volume Serial   - the volser the PANEXEC library is to reside on
   Space Allocation- number of cylinders to be allocated to the PANEXEC
                     library
   Maximum Elements- maximum number of elements on the PANEXEC library

 The following topics are presented only if selected by number:

        1 - CREATE JCL AND PANEXEC PROCEDURE
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000jd
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000j1
)END

PXP000J5.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - MODIFY ATTRIBUTES ---TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
The modify attributes option has 3 functions:
  1. It can modify the frequency of how often execution statistics of
individual elements on the library are changed.
  2. It can restrict the type of elements that can be executed from a
PANEXEC library by the status of the element.
  3. It can modify the default group, status and mode qualifiers of a
PANEXEC library. If any default qualifiers are to be modified then the D
File Update Option must be specified and the qualifiers to be
modified must be coded on the primary PANEXEC library utility panel.

  The following field must be specified on the library maintenance panel
   File Update Option - valid values are: A, F, J, N, D, P, T
                        Only one of A, F, J or N may be used. D, P and T
                        can be specified together and with either A, F, J or N
   See the PANEXEC system reference manual pages 6-47,48 for a description
   of the options.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000j1
)END

PXP000J6.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - RESTORE--------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+    The library restoration (selected members or all) procedure should
be run on an as needed basis to restore elements from a backup tape to a
PANEXEC library.

     The element name qualifiers must be specified on the primary
PANEXEC utility panel to indicate the element(s) to be restored to the
PANEXEC library.  A single element may be specified or groups of
elements may be specified by omitting the element name and coding any
combination of group, type, status and/or mode qualifiers.  * may be
coded as the element name (with group, type, status and mode blank)
which causes every element on the backup file to restored.

The following fields must be specified on the library maintenance panel:
 REPLACE LIKE-NAMED ELEMENTS- Indicates whether restored elements are to replace
 like named elements currently residing on the PANEXEC library.  Default=N.
 GENERATION DATA GROUP NUMBER- The relative or absolute generation
 number of the backup tape from which the elements to be restored reside
 on. If both relative and absolute numbers are specified, the relative
 number is used. The absolute number must specify 4 digits.

The following topics are presented only if selected by number:
        1 - RESTORE JCL and PANEXEC procedure
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000je
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000j1
)END

PXP000J7.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY MAINTENANCE - CONVERT -------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
     This procedure will convert an entire PDS library into a
new or pre-existing PANEXEC library. PANEXEC uses the member names
of the members on the PDS as the element names for the newly created
elements on the PANEXEC library. The group name, type, status and mode
qualifiers for the newly created elements must be specified on the
primary PANEXEC library utility panel.

The PDS name field must specify the DSN of the PDS to be converted.
If the PDS is not cataloged, the VOLSER of the volume it resides on
must also be supplied.

 The following topics are presented only if selected by number:
        1 - CONVERT JCL PROCEDURE
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000jf
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000j1
)END

PXP000K.text:
%TUTORIAL ------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - INPUT PANEXEC PROCEDURE------ TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%IN+function is used to input a PANEXEC procedure for execution.

+  To input a PANEXEC procedure, fill in the following fields on the
   library utility panel and press the%ENTER+key:

     - Enter%IN+in the option field.
     - Enter the PANEXEC library information that the PANEXEC input
       procedure will use as input.

   The actual name of the PANEXEC input procedure is specified on the
   second panel which will appear after ENTER is pressed.
   NOTE that if any additional input or output files are required by
   the PANEXEC input procedure (besides the PANEXEC library specified
   above), these files must be allocated using TSO ALLOCATE commands
   prior to executing the IN option (for an exception to this, see the
   commments on the REPORTS procedure in the second panel tutorial).

 The following topics will be presented only if selected by number:

    %1+- INPUT PANEXEC PROCEDURE - SECOND PANEL
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp001a1
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000L1.text:
%TUTORIAL -------- PANEXEC COMPILE AND LINK-EDITING ------------------  TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   The compile/link-edit option (CL) generates JCL for a compile and/or
   link-edit, based on information you enter on the compile/link-edit
   panel, and then submits the job for batch execution.

   The CL options supports several source languages (ASSEMBLER H, VS
   COBOL, VS COBOL OPTIMIZER, PL/I F, VS FORTRAN) and the Linkage Editor.
   Compiler and link-edit options may be specified (for defaults see the
   following panels).  One may choose to do a compile only or a link-edit
   only.  The origin of the source program must be specified as either a
   member of a PANVALET library or a partitioned data set or from a
   sequential data set. If a PANVALET member name is specified, it will
   be used, otherwise the source will be obtained from the specified PDS
   (if a PDS member is specified) or sequential data set.  The output
   load module element must be specified on the primary PANEXEC library
   utility panel (except when compiling only).  Additional MACRO/COPY libraries
   and link-edit control statements and JCL may also be generated.

 The following topics are presented only if selected by number:
        1 - Compiler and link-edit options
        2 - Additional link-edit control statements and JCL
        3 - Additional MACRO/COPY libraries
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp000l2
                2,*pxp000l3
                3,*pxp000l4
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000L2.text:
%TUTORIAL ------ PANEXEC - TRANSLATOR/LINKAGE EDITOR OPTIONS -----------TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
    Translator (link-editor) options are required only if one desires to
    override or add to the default compiler/assembler (link-edit) options.  If
    specified, the values must be enclosed in quotes and the first character
    must be a comma followed by the desired compiler (link-edit) options.

    The translator default options consist of the installation defaults (see
    appropiate programmers guide/linkage editor manuals for each language)
    plus the following options specified in the PANEXEC batch procedure:

    ASM: NODECK,OBJECT,XREF(SHORT)
    CVS: LOAD,SUPMAP,SYSX,SXREF,NOSEQ,NOADV
    FORT: NODECK,NOLIST,OPT(0)
    OPT: LOAD,SYSX,CSXREF,NOXCOUNT,NODTECT,NOPFLOW,MLIST,MDMAP,NOSEQ,NOADV
    PL1: LOAD,NODECK,NOLIST,NOSOURCE2,EXTDIC
    LK: LIST,LET,XREF (or MAP)

    PANEXEC/ISPF will remember the options you enter from session to session.

    Here is an example of how to specify translator/link editor options :
    TRANSLATOR OPTIONS      %===> ',DMAP,CLIST'+
    LINKAGE EDITOR OPTIONS  %===> ',MAP,TEST,RENT'+
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000l1
)END

PXP000L3.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC LINKAGE EDITOR CONTROL STATEMENTS AND JCL ------TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
   The Linkage edit panel allows you to generate additional link-edit
   control statements and JCL to execute the PANEXEC compile/link-edit
   procedure.  Control statements may be obtained either from a data set
   (PDS or sequential) or may be specified directly on the panel as in-
   stream control statements. Additional link-edit JCL DD statements may
   also be specified directly on the panel.

   Here is an example of how to specify linkage editor control and JCL
   statements:

   INSTREAM LINK-EDIT CONTROL STATEMENTS:
   ===> INCLUDE DD1(PROG1)
   ===> INCLUDE DD2(PROG2)

   ADDITIONAL LINK-EDIT JCL DD STATEMENTS:
   ===> //DD1 DD  DSN=INCLUDE.LIB1,DISP=SHR
   ===> //DD2 DD  DSN=INCLUDE.LIB2,DISP=SHR

   NOTE: If you are specifying additional link-edit statements and you are
         replacing an executable element in a PANEXEC library, then you must
         specify "NAME eltname(R)" as the last link-edit control statement.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000l1
)END

PXP000L4.text:
%TUTORIAL --- PANEXEC ADDITIONAL MACRO/COPY LIBRARIES FOR COMPILE/LKED ---------
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD
%
+  A maximum of 5 additional MACRO/COPY libraries may be specified.
   These libraries may either be PDSs or PANVALET libraries. If PANVALET
   libraries are specified, then the source program specified on the
   PANEXEC COMPILE/LINK-EDIT menu must be from a PANVALET library.

   There are no default libraries except for assembler (ASM) programs,
   in which case 'SYS1.MACLIB' and 'SYS1.AMODGEN' are automatically
   supplied as MACRO libraries. The concatenation order of the libraries
   is indicated by the numbers on the panel.

   Here is an example of specifying additional assembler MACRO libraries.
   These libraries will be concatenated to 'SYS1.MACLIB' and 'SYS1.AMODGEN'.

 +1%===>+'SYS1.HASPSRC'
 +2%===>+MY.ASM
 +3%===>+XYZ.MACROS
 +4%===>+'HRA.SOURCE'
 +5%===>+
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000l1
)END

PXP000M.text:
%TUTORIAL ------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - COPY ELEMENT----------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%copy element+function is used to copy a element of a PANEXEC
   library to the same or a different PANEXEC library.  (Use the%element
   list+option if you wish to copy several elements.)

+  To perform a copy operation, fill in the following fields on the
   library utility panel and press the%ENTER+key:

     - Enter%C+in the option field.
     - Enter the%"from"+library information in the appropriate fields.
     - Enter an element name in the element field.

 The following topics will be presented only if selected by number:

    %1+- copy utility - second panel
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp001a1
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000N.text:
)attr default(¢+_)
)body
¢TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - PRINT ELEMENT---------------- TUTORIAL
¢OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The¢print element+function is used to print the contents of an element.
   The listing is printed to a SYSOUT class specified in the primary PANEXEC
   panel. (Use the¢element list+option if you wish to print several
   elements). Executable elements (type=EXEC) are printed in hexadecimal
   dump format (see description of the %PRINT,D command in the PANEXEC
   system reference manual) and CNTL elements (PANEXEC procedures) are
   printed 'as is' in character format.

   To print a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter¢P+in the option field.
       - Enter the¢library+information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the¢element+field
       - Enter a one-character SYSOUT print class

)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000O.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - MODIFY MODE OF ELEMENT------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%modify mode+function is used to modify the mode of an element of
   a PANEXEC library.  (Use the%element list+option if you wish to
   modify the mode of several elements.)

   To modify the mode of a single element, fill in the following fields
   of the library utility panel:
       - Enter%M+in the option field.
       - Enter the%library information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the%element+field.
       - Enter the new mode in the%new mode+field. Valid modes are
         A (active), D (disabled), I (inactive).
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000P.text:
%TUTORIAL ----------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - EDIT ELEMENT ---- ------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
  %The PANEXEC edit function allows you to create or change PANEXEC
   procedures (elements whose type=CNTL).  (Use the%element list+option
   if you wish to edit several elements.)

   To edit a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter%E+in the option field.
       - Enter the%library+information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the%element+field.

   When you press the ENTER key, the element will be displayed via the ISPF
   edit function. If the element is being created then one blank line will be
   displayed when ENTER is pressed.  All edit commands may be used.  Please
   refer to the appropiate IBM ISPF manuals for more information on edit.
   NOTE that PANEXEC/ISPF does NOT provide an edit recovery environment.

   Note that PANEXEC/ISPF places the CNTL element that is to be edited
   into a sequential data set (whose DSN will appear at the top of the
   panel) from which the element may be edited. This data set is deleted
   after the element is saved back into the PANEXEC library or the edit
   session is cancelled.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000Q.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - RENAME ELEMENT--------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%rename element+function is used to rename a element of a PANEXEC
   library.  (Use the%element list+option if you wish to rename several
   elements.)

   To rename a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter%R+in the option field.
       - Enter the%library information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the old element name in the%element+field.
       - Enter the new element name in the%new elt+field and/or
       - Enter the new group name in the%new grp+field

)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000R.text:
%TUTORIAL ------PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - DELETE ELEMENT--------------- TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%delete element+function is used to delete an element of a PANEXEC
   library.  (Use the%element list+option if you wish to delete several
   elements.) The mode of the element to be deleted must be either I
   (inactive) or D (disabled).

   To delete a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter%D+in the option field.
       - Enter the%library+information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the%element+field.

 Elements may NOT be deleted from the PANEXEC System Residence Library
 via the PANEXEC/ISPF dialog (this function may only be performed in
 batch mode).

 The following topics will be presented only if selected by number:

    %1+- Confirm delete panel
)PROC
   &ZSEL = TRANS(&ZCMD
                1,*pxp002a
                )
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000S.text:
)attr default(¢+_)
)body
¢TUTORIAL ------------ PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - BROWSE ELEMENT---------TUTORIAL
¢OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The¢browse element+function is used to browse an element of a PANEXEC
   library. (Use the¢element list+option if you wish to browse several
   elements.)  Executable elements (type=EXEC) are browsed in hexadecimal dump
   format (see description of the %PRINT,D command in the PANEXEC system
   reference manual) and CNTL elements (PANEXEC procedures) are browsed 'as is'
   in character format. Ensure that the DISPLAY CC command is in effect.

   To browse a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter¢B+in the option field.
       - Enter the¢library+information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the¢element+field

   When you press the ENTER key, the element will be displayed via the
   ISPF browse function.  All browse commands may be used.  Please refer
   to the appropiate IBM ISPF manuals for more information on browse.

   Note that PANEXEC/ISPF places the element that is to be browsed into
   a sequential data set (whose DSN will appear at the top of the panel)
   from which the element may be browsed. This data set is deleted after
   the browse session is completed.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000T1.text:
%TUTORIAL -------- PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILITY - ZAP ELEMENT ---------------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The%zap element+function is used to zap an element of a PANEXEC
   library. It may also be used to display an executable element (load
   module) map, cross-reference and statistics with or without zapping
   the element.  (Use the%element list+option if you wish to zap several
   elements.)

   The zap function should be used with extreme caution, since any
   changes made to the executable element do not have any corresponding
   source module change documentation.

   To zap a single element, fill in the following fields of the library
   utility panel:
       - Enter%Z+in the option field.
       - Enter the%library information in the appropriate fields.
       - Enter the element name in the%element+field.

                    (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
   &Zcont = pxp000t2
)END

PXP000T2.text:
%TUTORIAL ----- PANEXEC LIBRARY UTILTIY - ZAP SECOND PANEL -------------TUTORIAL
%OPTION  ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  Fill in the following fields on the%second panel:

     - If the zapped output element is to be different than the original
       element specify the appropiate name information in the OUTPUT
       ZAPPED ELEMENT fields

+  Up to 6 options (in any combination) may be specified in the
   SPECIFY ZAP OPTIONS field. They are:

        C - allow partial update without verification (use with extreme caution)
        M - produce CSECT map.
        N - causes zap control statements not to be listed.
        R - replace like-named element when OUTPUT ZAPPED ELELMENT specified
        S - produce a statistics report for the zapped element.
        X - produce a cross reference listing for the input element & CSECT map

   The remainder of the panel allows entry of any of the zap subcommands.
   The subcommands (CSECT, BASE, IDRDATA, VER, REP) must be entered in
   the format described in the PANEXEC manual on pages 4-129 thru 136.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000t1
)END

PXP000U.text:
%TUTORIAL -------- PANEXEC MESSAGE LOGGING ---------------------------- TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
+  The PANEXEC/ISPF dialog has the ability to log messages to the user's
   ISPF LOG data set.  To turn this facility on or off simply specify Y
   or N in the LOG field of the primary PANEXEC utility panel. This
   field may even be changed in the middle of a PANEXEC/ISPF session.
   The LOG data set may be viewed in ISPF/PDF option 7.5.

   Only messages indicating the successful completion of a function,
   together with the element on which the function operated, are
   recorded in the LOG data set. In addition, the successful completion
   messages of the SAVE and SORT commands are unconditionally logged.

   The current LOG data set is &zlogname.
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000V.text:
%TUTORIAL -------------PANEXEC LIBRARY INTEGRITY ---------------------- TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
      The PANEXEC/ISPF dialog enforces library integrity by utilizing
      the IBM ENQ/DEQ facility to ensure that PANEXEC elements that are
      in use cannot be updated by another user (or the same user in
      split screen). For example, a user cannot rename an element if
      that element is currently being edited by another user.

      The MAJOR name (QNAME) used is SPFPANX.
      The MINOR name (RNAME) is the PANEXEC library name followed by the
      fully qualified element name.
                                                                        .
      To determine if an element of a PANEXEC library is in use issue
      the TSO/E command:

            DENQ SPFPANX/*

      which will display all the PANEXEC elements being enqueued upon.

      NOTE: To ensure the proper functioning of the ENQ/DEQ mechanism
      it is imperative that the element name be specified with all of
      its qualifiers (group, element, type, status amd mode).
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
)END

PXP000W1.text:
%TUTORIAL ---------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY SECURITY --------------------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
     TOP SECRET security is in place for the PANEXEC facility and
PANEXEC libraries on several levels through a PANEXEC security exit
interface program. This security is provided above and beyond the native
PANEXEC security which is based on a multi-level password system. The
use of native PANEXEC security will not be allowed to unauthorized users
of batch PANEXEC and PANEXEC/ISPF provides no means of entering PANEXEC
passwords.

     On the first level, TOP SECRET places restrictions on executing
PANEXEC functions. The following require TOP SECRET authorization
before they can be executed:

    L  -   library maintenance
    PM -   promoting PANEXEC elements to production status

     To acquire authorization to execute these options, update access is
required to the PANEXEC system residence library, 'HRA.PANESRL'.  Only
authorized personnel (tech services and console operations) may invoke
the restricted L option PANEXEC/ISPF panel.

                          (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
   &Zcont = pxp000w2
)END

PXP000W2.text:
%TUTORIAL --------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY SECURITY ---------------------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
     The second level of security restricts the deletion of active
elements from a PANEXEC library.  This is in addition to the
restrictions placed on accessing elements which are in production
status. Each PANEXEC command documents its own limitations as regards
production elements and will not be discussed here.

     The third and most extensive level of TOP SECRET security is
element level protection based on group name and element prefix.
Users will be required to request either read or update access to
elements on a PANEXEC library by specifying:
  - the PANEXEC library name
  - the group name of the element
  - the element prefix

     The typical PANEXEC security violation error message for restricted
restricted functions is:
  PS053 08-XX SECURITY VIOLATION - FUNCTION NOT ALLOWED.

                          (continued on next page)
)PROC
   &ZUP = pxp000a
   &Zcont = pxp000w3
)END

PXP000W3.text:
%TUTORIAL --------------- PANEXEC LIBRARY SECURITY ---------------------TUTORIAL
%COMMAND ===>_ZCMD                                                             +
+
